repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Second Power Transmission and
            Distribution Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that the
            project's objectives for restructuring of the power
            sector for competition and private sector participation
            along with major investments in physical infrastructure
            would have been challenging under favorable circumstances
            and could have been jeopardized by the economic crisis that
            affected Indonesia and other Asian countries during 1997-98.
            The restructuring of a power sector from a government-owned
            monopoly to a competitive market system is likely to require
            a long time, depending on the preparatory work to create the
            necessary legal framework. Bank called attention to delays
            due to extended procurement cycles and problems with land
            acquisition for transmission projects. In addition, the SAR
            cited the use of outdated cost estimates by Perusahaan
            Listrik Negara (The State Electricity Corporation) PLN and
            shortcomings in the performance of technical assistance
            components due to limited absorptive capacity. The
            mitigation measures the SAR proposed to deal with these
            problems were the implementing agency's agreement to
            use standardized procurement documents; the fostering of
            "ownership" of the technical assistance by the
            implementing units within PLN; and PLN's use of updated
            prices in preparing cost estimates. Nevertheless, the
            project experienced all of the implementation problems that
            were supposed to be mitigated.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Second Power Transmission and
            Distribution Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Power
            Transmission and Distribution Project is to improve customer
            service by: (1) increasing the physical capacity,
            efficiency, and reliability of the Java-Bali transmission
            system and distribution network; and (2) promoting sector
            efficiency, competition, and private sector participation by
            implementing functional decentralization of State
            Electricity Corporation (PLN) operations in Java-Bali and
            developing effective regulatory oversight and institutions.
            The project has two principal components: (1) the
            restructuring of and investment in PLN's operations;
            and (2) the development of regulatory oversight.
